The rate of two teachers working together is the sum of their individual rates, and I can use this to find the rate of one teacher. Then I can use the rate of one teacher to find the time it takes for one teacher to grade the same amount of tests.<eot>
turn_1.MOSS: <|MOSS|>: If two teachers can grade a stack of 50 tests in 7 hours, then the rate at which they work together is 50 tests divided by (2 teachers times 7 hours), which is 3.57 tests per hour. Therefore, the rate at which one teacher works is half of that, which is 1.79 tests per hour. To grade the same amount of tests, one teacher would need to work at this rate, so it would take one teacher approximately 3.57 hours to grade 50 tests.<eom>

When the two workers work together, their combined rate is "r + r/2 = 3r/2". We know that they can complete the project in 10 days, so their combined work rate is (1 project)/(10 days) = 1/10. 

Using these equations, we can solve for "r" as follows: 

3r/2 = 1/10 

r = 1/10 * 2/3 = 1/15 

Therefore, the faster worker's rate is 1/15 of the project per day, and the slower worker's rate is half of that, or 1/30 of the project per day. 

To find out how long each worker takes to complete the project alone, we can use the formula of "time = work/rate". For the faster worker, this is (1 project)/(1/15 project per day) = 15 days. For the slower worker, this is (1 project)/(1/30 project per day) = 30 days.
